Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Collaborative Research: Timing and Molecular Origins of Recently Evolved Chiton Shell-Eyes: Phylogenomics of Chitonina
Award.AbstractNarration:
Chitons (Mollusca: Polyplacophora) are ecologically important marine invertebrate animals common on rocky shores. They typically have eight overlapping shell plates supplied with numerous sensory organs, which in certain lineages are further developed into tiny image-forming shell-eyes. Chiton shell-eyes are the only eyes known to focus light using lenses made of the calcium carbonate - mineral aragonite. This study will establish how many times, when, where, and how shell-eyes evolved in chitons, employing phylogenetic analyses from DNA for most living chiton species, plus fossils. Chitons are well suited for investigating the origin and evolution of eyes because there is considerable variation in shell-eye morphology that permits comparative studies, behavioral and molecular experiments are feasible, and chiton shell-eyes evolved recently compared to the eyes of other animals.

This grant will benefit society because chitons have unique traits including not only mineral-based lenses but also magnetite-coated teeth used for feeding and a robust and flexible form of natural armor that are of interest to the field of biologically-inspired design. Better understanding of chiton relationships will help researchers use comparative methods to study these traits and others. The grant will help develop a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce by funding the training of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral researchers and fostering collaboration between research- and teaching-oriented universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit 

Chitons are molluscs in Class Polyplacophora that have eight overlapping shell plates. These shell plates contain clusters of sensory cells called aesthetes. In some chiton species, aesthetes are modified to include an eyespot, and in others, aesthetes are present in addition to “shell eyes” with a lens and retina. This study addressed the hypothesis that these “shell eyes” of chitons may be the most recent independent origin of a lensed eye in animals. To test this hypothesis, we generated a phylogenetic tree based on sequences from transcriptomes, which are expressed genes sequenced from chiton RNA. We are expanding this phylogeny using targeted regions of genomic DNA, or target-capture phylogenomics. The transcriptome approach requires RNA extraction from recently-collected samples, whereas the target-capture approach allows us to use older museum samples that are preserved for DNA extraction. We have generated a set of probes for this target-capture protocol using our transcriptome data and sequences from distantly-related mollusc genomes. Most target-capture protocols require whole genome sequences from the group of interest, so our approach and probe-design pipeline will be a valuable contribution to the field of phylogenomics of non-model organisms. This pipeline will be made available on bioinformatics repositories.  

To test the hypothesis that chitons have the most recently-evolved lensed eye, it is necessary to estimate the ages of other lensed eye origins in animals. In Spring 2018, PI Oakley and Postdoc Cannon co-instructed an honor’s course for undergraduates at UCSB where students directly engaged this question via literature-based research.  The students in the course generated estimates of eight lens eye origins across animal diversity, indicating that these structures evolved in the Precambrian, Cambrian, or as recently as the late Devonian.

A significant result of our collaborative research has been the discovery that the aesthetes of the eyeless chitons Chaetopleuraapiculata and Mopalia muscosa genes that indicate that they have the molecular components necessary for light-sensitivity. 

We published five research papers, and have given eight conference presentations related to this funding.  We deposited data in public data banks (Dryad, GenBank). We made bioinformatics tools available in the Galaxy platform in a set of phylogenetics tools called Osiris, which are available on the public repository github.

Broader Impacts

To promote teaching, training, and learning, this project has funded two postdoctoral researchers, Dr. Daniel Speiser and Dr. Johanna Cannon. Dr. Speiser is now a faculty member at the University of South Carolina. Dr. Cannon has an interest in teaching and including undergraduates in research, and has taught or co-instructed three courses at UCSB. 

Dr. Cannon gives regular presentations at Santa Barbara County middle schools as part of FUSE (Family Ultimate Science Experience), an evening program sponsored by UCSB where students and their families conduct fun experiments while interacting with STEM researchers. She also particpates in I <3 STEM, a one-day conference aimed at promoting STEM literacy for female students in grades 9-12. 

In Spring 2018, PI Oakley and Postdoc Cannon co-instructed an honor’s course for undergraduates at UCSB where students directly engaged in literature-based research centered around the question of timing of eye origins. Two undergraduate students from this course are now continuing this project in the Oakley lab and are preparing a manuscript for publication in an undergraduate reseach journal. 

This funding has additionally contributed to training one PhD student, one technician, and 15 undergraduate students at UCSB.
